title: 114_hr3295
content: The following sums are appropriated for fiscal year 2015 from the Treasury for the Department of Justice, specifically for state and local law enforcement assistance under the Office of Justice Programs. $140,000,000 is allocated for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance, including funds for the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. $10,000,000 is allocated for Juvenile Justice Programs for community-based violence prevention initiatives, including public health approaches to reducing shootings and violence. Additionally, funding is provided for Community Oriented Policing Services programs. $30,000,000 is allocated for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, with $15,000,000 for grants to State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States for investigative purposes, and $15,000,000 for grants to statewide law enforcement agencies. $15,000,000 is allocated for competitive grants to statewide law enforcement agencies in States with high rates of primary treatment admissions for heroin and other opioids for investigative purposes related to illicit activities and trafficking. The Small Business Administration receives an additional $4,000,000 for entrepreneurial development programs and $1,000,000 for business loans program account. The Department of Labor's Employment and Training Administration is allocated funds for training and employment services. An additional $265,000,000 is allocated for training and employment services. The Health Resources and Services Administration receives $50,000,000 for the Healthy Start Initiative, and the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration receives funding for substance abuse treatment. An additional $10,000,000 is allocated for drug court grants for substance abuse treatment. $170,000,000 is allocated for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative under the Department of Housing and Urban Development. $500,000,000 is allocated for the Community Development Fund for emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas impacted by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be awarded to states, tribes, or local governments as grants. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may grant funds to distressed communities with insufficient capacity to recover from an unanticipated event. Criteria for distress include high levels of racial or income segregation, low employment rates, poor-performing schools, high infant mortality, vacant homes, and proximity to brownfields. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may grant funds to distressed communities with insufficient capacity to recover from an unanticipated event, including those in close proximity to brownfields or environmentally hazardous areas. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage, eligibility criteria, and how funds will support long-term recovery, infrastructure, housing, and economic revitalization in distressed areas. The Secretary will specify approval criteria within 45 days of the Act's enactment. If a plan is deemed inadequate, the Secretary will take action. The Secretary will disapprove plans that do not meet criteria, funds under this heading are not relevant to non-emergency formula allocations, grantees must receive training on grant management and incorporate performance requirements into contracts or subrecipient agreements. The Secretary has the authority to waive or specify alternative requirements for contracts or subrecipient agreements related to the use of funds, except for certain specified areas, if good cause exists and it aligns with the overall purposes of the Housing and Community Development Act. The Secretary may use up to 30 percent of funds for immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization assistance. Up to $10,000,000 may be transferred for program office salaries and expenses. The Housing and Urban Development--Office of Inspector General may use necessary costs, including information technology costs, for administering and overseeing funds under this heading. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028 with the same terms, except for mutually agreed changes. Reserve balances exceeding four months of operating expenses will remain available for agency use. Moving-to-Work agencies must report financial data to HUD as specified by the Secretary for policy change measurement. The Act provides emergency funding designated by Congress, subject to the President's approval. It is known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
